pageData.text: Earth’s soil plays a major role in the world’s agriculture and has a substantial effect on water availability in a given area. In this investigation, the student will analyze the natural <button class='glossary-text'>porosity</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>particle size</button> of soil samples along with the chemical composition and profile of different soil types.

pageData.text: One of the consequences of mankind’s agricultural and industrial activities is the runoff of pollutants into estuaries and coastal waters. The most dangerous components of these waste chemicals are nitrogen and phosphorus. These elements are vital nutrients for photosynthetic algae, just like they are for crops. In the presence of these chemicals, the algae grow at an exponential rate, creating algal blooms so large they can sometimes be seen from space. <span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>In 2018, an annual algal bloom called the great Atlantic sargassum belt became the largest algal bloom ever recorded. It spanned 5,000 miles, from the coast of West Africa to the Gulf of Mexico. Although sargassum blooms serve as an important refuge for hundreds of marine species, super-sized blooms harm coastal biodiversity, fisheries, the tourism industry, and human health. As the 2018 bloom decayed on beaches around the world, its effects on the Caribbean country of Barbados were so devastating it declared a national emergency. It is predicted the great Atlantic sargassum belt will continue to increase in size due to climate change, changing ocean currents, and the continued use of agricultural and industrial chemicals.

pageData.subTitle: Soil Horizons and Chemical Composition
pageData.text: The type of dirt that makes up the dry surfaces of the Earth has numerous effects on humans and the environment, and vice versa. Humans can modify the suitability of some areas for agriculture based on prior land use. The properties of soil also determine water availability in a given area. Areas that contain the most suitable soil for farming are often limited.

Certain properties of soil determine whether an area is suitable for human activity. When considering the properties of soil, <button class='glossary-text'>texture</button>, shape, particle aggregation, and suitability for growth come to mind. These properties all play a major role in determining the capability of an area to retain water and air, which are necessary for several agricultural processes that are vital to human life.

It is important to understand the profile and chemical composition of soil to understand how they affect agriculture and water availability. For instance, some farmlands have been plowed for hundreds of years yet the soil remains very fertile. However, in other areas with a similar history, much of the soil has been adversely affected (over one-third of the soil in the United States is now deemed as destroyed). With years of continuously turning over the soil to cultivate crops, the damage accumulates and many areas are left vulnerable to erosion, weathering, and deterioration of nutrient and organic material. Why then is there such great disparity in the way certain soils flourish? It is because of the various layers, or <button class='glossary-text'>horizons</button>, of the soil.

Soils differ greatly depending on the proportion of each of these horizons
(see ). If you were to dig a hole or to drive a corer (a special drill that uses a hollow steel tube to remove a cylindrical dirt sample) deep into the ground to extract a sample of soil, a visible color difference would be evident in the , or horizon composition. The colors of various horizons differ based on the organic content and mineral composition of each soil. Each horizon can also vary in texture, which is determined by the makeup of sand, silt, or clay.

As shown in Figure 1:
  • The is the most nutrient-rich part of the mainly because of its abundance in organic matter. This layer is often referred to as the layer and is usually dark brown or black in color.
  • The , also known as , is the next layer down. This layer contains some organic matter in addition to a mixture of minerals. This tends to be lighter black to brown in color.
  • Further down is the , or the . Much of the soil in this region has undergone some degree of weathering and is composed almost entirely of mineral material. Its high iron and clay content usually imparts a reddish color.
  • The is generally composed of weathered rock fragments and material from the layers above.
  • The lowest region is known as the (sometimes referred to as the ), which mostly consists of unaltered bedrock material.

It is important to note that all these layers are not necessarily present in every soil profile and the proportions of each layer can vary drastically among various soil samples. Thus, with the farmland example earlier, much of the fertile soil may have had thicker O- and A-horizons, making it more suitable for agriculture even after many years, whereas the damaged soil may have had much thinner top layers. The ages of these soils may make a considerable difference as well. Older soils tend to have almost all horizons present, and younger soils tend to have far fewer horizons.

pageData.text: Identifying Soil Types: Texture and Structure In addition to distinguishing the chemical and biological makeup of soil, it is also important to understand the impact of soil on water availability in a given area. is one of the most important aspects of soil type descriptions that helps to determine the holding capacity of the soil as well as its ability to filter water. The size of soil particles determines their , which can be classified into smaller subcategories (primary units) depending on the mineral components of the soil. Texture is determined by the ratio of sand, silt, and clay in the soil sample (see Table 1).

Every soil sample will have different proportions of these primary units. Based on these proportions, each soil sample can be further categorized and identified. Figure 2 shows a soil analysis chart that illustrates the different classes of soil based on their combinations of sand, silt, and clay. <button class='glossary-text'>Loam</button> is a close-to-equal mixture of these three primary units and can be used to identify multiple soil types.

pageData.text: Determining <button class='glossary-text'>particle size</button> (based on these subcategories of soil <button class='glossary-text'>texture</button>) is the first step in soil characterization. The next step is determining the <button class='glossary-text'>structure</button> of the soil, which defines how the individual particles aggregate. The soil structure affects how easily air, water, and the roots of plants are able to move within the soil. The arrangement of soil particle aggregates can be broken down into <button class='glossary-text'>peds</button>, or secondary units of the primary soil particles—sand, silt, and clay (see Figure 3).

pageData.desc: Figure 3: Examples of soil peds: platy, blocky, granular, and columnar
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Examples of soil peds: platy, blocky, granular, and columnar

pageData.text: Knowing the type of soil present by first identifying the primary and secondary particle types can help determine whether the soil is suitable for agriculture. Soil <button class='glossary-text'>permeability</button> (ability of water to flow through a soil) is directly related to the particle size (texture) and the aggregation of those particles (structure). Rounded, granular peds are particularly suitable for plant growth because their structure easily permits penetration by air, water, and roots. Clay and loamy soils often have blocky peds that are angular and somewhat irregular in shape and permit the flow of air and water. In platy peds, however, some passageways are blocked because the soil particles are tightly packed. A platy soil usually has high clay content and often occurs in areas that are frequently flooded. These classifications are not applicable to sand because of its inability to form aggregates; thus, instead of clumping, it falls apart.

The roots of plants require air and water. Just as it can die from lack of water, a plant can also die in waterlogged soil owing to a lack of air. Soil must retain water and permit root penetration to support plant life. However, certain particle sizes and arrangements of particles allow for permeability conditions that could be detrimental to agriculture. Therefore, particle size and arrangement need to be identified to determine proper soil usage. <button class='glossary-text'>Porosity</button> is the amount of void space between individual soil particles. With high porosity between particles, a greater volume of water can permeate but might also waterlog certain systems. Porosity is another major property of soil that has a significant effect on water infiltration and <button class='glossary-text'>soil fertility</button>, or the ability of soil to hold sufficient nutrients for plant growth. In the following section, nutrient availability and chemical composition-and their effects on different soil types-are discussed.

pageData.text: Processes Affecting the Fertility of Soil Determining the productivity of the soil in a given area is crucial. The or the number of hydrogen ions present in the soil, is a major indicator of . The pH scale ranges from 0 to 14, with a value of 7 being neutral. Anything less than 7 is acidic, and anything greater than 7 is considered basic (Figure 4).

pageData.desc: Figure 4: A pH scale showing the pHs of common household substances.
pageData.altText: Figure 4: A pH scale showing the pHs of common household substances.

pageData.text: This scale is logarithmic, so if a solution has a pH of 6, it has ten times the number of hydrogen ions (or is ten times more acidic) than a solution with a pH of 7 possesses. There are wide ranges of pH for a variety of soils; for example, quartz-rich sandstone is rather acidic, whereas limestone tends to be basic.

Rainwater, which has a pH of approximately 5.5, has a significant impact on soil pH. The low pH of rainwater is caused by the mixing of water with carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. Carbonic acid is formed when the precipitation makes contact with the Earth’s surface. As this rainwater flows into and along soil surfaces, it transmits many nutrients into the depths of the soil. Iron, along with other minerals such as calcium and magnesium, tends to flow through the higher <button class='glossary-text'>horizons</button>, which are usually flourishing with life, and continues into the lower horizons that tend to be lacking in nutrients.

Besides pH, <button class='glossary-text'>decomposition</button> is another important factor in determining the health of soil. Organisms such as bacteria and fungi decompose (break down) organic matter that plants and animals produce at the surface and deposit into the soil, allowing for the survival of organisms deeper in the soil. The rate of decomposition can be increased by worms and other organisms living near the surface. These organisms break down detritus (debris and waste) into smaller bits that sink farther into the soil, feeding the bacteria and fungi.

Nutrients are essential for plant growth. One major issue regarding the health of certain soil types in some areas is the inability of the soil to retain sufficient nutrients. Adding fertilizers and pesticides helps replenish crops and soil, but an excess of these nutrients can also exert negative effects. <button class='glossary-text'>Macronutrients</button> are nutrients needed at high concentrations by all living things. Nitrogen, potassium, phosphate, and magnesium are examples of these nutrients necessary for plant growth. <button class='glossary-text'>Micronutrients</button>-such as the metals zinc, iron, and copper-are those needed in smaller quantities.

Fertilizers are useful to replace macronutrients lost from the soil. Many fertilizers, such as manure, are either purely or mostly organic matter; however, numerous synthetic fertilizers have also been developed. Nitrogen, phosphorous, and potassium are commonly regarded as the limiting nutrients in crop production and are therefore typically added to soils in specific amounts via fertilizers.

Nitrogen is a special case; plants require nitrogen in the form of ammonium or nitrate, and atmospheric nitrogen can only be converted synthetically, or by soildwelling microbes, as part of the nitrogen cycle. Additional ways in which nitrogen can enter the soil include via the death and <button class='glossary-text'>decomposition</button> of plants and by the production of nitrogenous waste from plants being eaten by animals. Nitrogen is vital for plant growth; it is a very important structural component of chlorophyll, the compound used by plants in photosynthesis to produce oxygen and sugars. Nitrogen is also a major component of amino acids, which are the building blocks of proteins. Since it is not retained by soil, excess nitrogen can leach onto the surface or into groundwater, causing algal blooms and a loss of oxygen. Although nitrogen is an essential element, because it is not retained by the soil, farmers frequently need to reapply fertilizers containing nitrates, which in turn can lead to environmental challenges.

Phosphorus is usually present in the form of phosphates in the soil. Phosphate is an important component of adenosine triphosphate/adenosine diphosphate (ATP/ADP) in plants and is therefore necessary for energy transport and storage. Phosphates, along with pentose sugars, make up the backbone of DNA and RNA. Phosphorus availability frequently limits plant growth and flowering; therefore, the introduction of phosphates into soil can lead to rapid plant growth. This element also plays a major role in keeping the root systems of plants strong and thriving. However, like excess nitrates, too much phosphorus can lead to algal blooms, which can harm aquatic ecosystems.

The last main nutrient in fertilizer is known as potash. It is a mixture of various salts that contain soluble potassium, which is vital for the development of many flowers and fruits. Potassium is required for the activation of numerous enzymes and the regulation of pH as well. It also controls the opening and closing of the stomata (pores in the leaves), which affects photosynthesis, water and gas transport, and temperature regulation.

In this investigation, you will conduct experiments to determine the <button class='glossary-text'>texture</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>structure</button> of soil samples as well as the ability of water to permeate each sample. You’ll also perform chemical tests to determine the fertility of two soil samples.

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for activities 1 and 2 of this investigation. Before beginning the investigation, collect a soil sample. In activity 1, stratify the soil layers in the known and collected soil samples. Then, compare the layer types in the collected soil to the known soil. Next, measure the depth of each layer and the total depth of the collected soil sample in the test tube. Then, calculate the particle size distribution of the collected soil. Next, determine the texture of the collected soil sample. In activity 2, you will assemble the filtration apparatus with the soil sample. Then, pour water into the apparatus. Then, measure the time it takes for the first drop of water to emerge from the apparatus. When you have tested all soil samples, proceed to activity 3.

A map describing the procedural workflow for activities 3 and 4 of this investigation. After completing activity 2, in activity 3, you will need to collect an additional soil sample. Then, fill the pH test chamber with a collected soil sample up to the line. Next, use the test capsule powder to perform the soil color change test and compare the color to the soil to the pH color chart. Then, record the pH of the sample and rinse the container. You will complete this test for both collected soil samples. In activity 4, you will leach the nutrients from the collected soils into liquid supernatants. Then, fill the nitrogen, phosphorous and potash test chambers with supernatant. Next, use the test capsule powder to perform the soil color change test and compare the color to the soil to the color chart. Finally, record the nutrient contents of the sample and rinse the container. You will complete this test for both collected soil samples.

pageData.text: Take three test tubes from the equipment kit and label them “Sand,” “Clay,” and “Collected Soil” (one for each sample).
Fill each test tube halfway with its designated soil sample. For each test tube, add tap water to about 1 cm below the top and, with gloved hands, place your thumb over the opening.

Shake each test tube for 30 seconds. Add one drop of liquid hand soap to each sample to help settle the particles. Allow the samples to settle overnight in the test tube rack. Place a piece of paper over the top of the three test tubes to prevent contamination of the samples.
pageData.desc: stopwatch symbol
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Place a sheet of white paper behind the test tubes containing the settled soil samples, and observe the layers that have formed in each.
Using the “Sand” and “Clay” samples as controls, identify the layer types in the “Collected Soil” sample. You may use a marker to label each layer. See Figure 5 for guidance.

Use a ruler to measure (in centimeters) the depth of the sand, silt, and clay layers in the “Collected Soil” sample. The silt layer is the layer formed between the clay and sand layers, owing to its that is larger than that of clay but smaller than that of sand (see Figure 5). Record these values in Data Table 1.

pageData.desc: Figure 5: Three test tubes illustrating the depth of layers of clay and sand in two of the test tubes and an example of layers of sand, silt, clay, water, and humus in a collected soil sample
pageData.altText: Figure 5: Three test tubes illustrating the depth of layers of clay and sand in two of the test tubes and an example of layers of sand, silt, clay, water, and humus in a collected soil sample

pageData.text: All layers may not be visible or may vary substantially in depth in the “Collected Soil” sample.
Measure the total depth of the soil. Be careful to exclude the humus layer containing floating dirt and grasses at the top of the sample (see Figure 5).

Calculate the distribution of the “Collected Soil” sample by dividing the depth of each layer by the total depth of the soil, then multiplying that value by 100. Record the percentages of the primary particles clay, silt, and sand in the “Collected Soil” sample in Data Table 1.

Note: In , each corner of the triangle represents 100% of one of the three types of soil: silt, sand, and clay. Locate these points. Loam is found in the center of the triangle. Following the arrows on the sides of the triangle, start by pointing to the percentage of your soil sample that is composed of silt (from ) on the right edge of the triangle. With your other hand, point to the percentage composed of sand along the bottom edge. Following the corresponding diagonal lines, move your fingers toward each other until the lines intersect. (If you have found the correct intersecting lines, the percentage of clay of your sample should line up horizontally on the left edge from the point at which your fingers meet). This point of intersection represents the class of soil texture; if the point falls on a boundary between two types, choose the one that occupies a larger area. Also, if the percentage of either silt or sand is less than 10% for your specific “Collected Soil” sample, start your fingers on clay and the existing primary particle and follow the same process.

typeBefore.text: For Activities 3 and 4, use the soil from the initial collection in the “Preparation” section (the “Collected Soil” sample). For the other soil sample, collect a sample of your choice—for example, this can be commercial potting soil, soil from a different outdoor location, or any remaining clay from this lab. Avoid using any remaining sand since it carries little nutritional value due to its large pore space.Ideally, the best option is to find another soil sample from a different outdoor location with contrasting properties. For example, if your collected soil sample was from a very dry area without plants, try to find a very moist soil sample that is covered with grass. You can also select a deeper soil sample as a comparison of the surface based collected soil sample.

Then, cut the template to the lowest contour line. Next, roll out the clay into a thin sheet, cut the clay in the shape of the template, and place the clay shape into the plastic tray. Then, trim the map to the next contour line and repeat the process until your island has 4 layers.  In activity 2, prepare the salt water. Then, place the colored ice cube in the plastic tray and add the salt water, Next, estimate the initial water depth. Then, place coins on the island and estimate the depth of the water every 10 minutes until the ice has completely melted. Finally, observe if the coins are underwater before removing them and draining the water from the tray. Then continue to activity 3.

Then, place the colored ice cube on the clay island and add the salt water. Next, estimate the initial water depth. Then, place coins on the island and estimate the depth of the water every 30 minutes until the ice has completely melted. Next, observe if the coins are underwater before removing them and draining the water from the tray. In activity 4, prepare the salt water, add the pH indicator, and add the solution to the plastic tray. Then, measure the pH of the tray water. Next, place an Alka-Seltzer solution cup on the island. Then, observe color changes in the tray water at regular intervals for 60 minutes. Finally, observe the final color of the tray water. In activity 5, improve or expand on the model from activity 4.

data.title: A-horizon
data.content: The horizon of a soil profile just below the O-horizon (if present); it contains some organic matter in addition to a mixture of minerals; also called topsoil

data.title: B-horizon
data.content: The horizon of a soil profile just below the A-horizon (if present); it contains soil with some degree of weathering and is composed almost entirely of mineral material; also called subsoil

data.title: C-horizon
data.content: The horizon of a soil profile just below the B-horizon (if present); it is generally composed of weathered rock fragments and material from any layers above

data.title: Decomposition
data.content: The process of recycling nutrients from deceased organisms and organic debris

data.title: D-horizon
data.content: The deepest horizon in a soil profile; it consists of unaltered bedrock material; also called the R-layer

data.title: Horizon
data.content: A soil layer parallel to the surface whose physical, chemical, and biological characteristics differ from the layers above and beneath

data.title: Humus
data.content: Dark organic matter

data.title: Loam
data.content: A close-to-equal mixture of sand, silt, and clay that can be used to identify multiple soil types

data.title: Macronutrient
data.content: A nutrient needed at high concentrations by all living things

data.title: Micronutrient
data.content: A nutrient needed at lower concentrations by living things

data.title: O-horizon
data.content: The uppermost horizon of a soil profile; it is the most nutrient-rich part of the soil profile due its abundance of organic matter; also called the humus layer

data.title: Particle size
data.content: A characteristic of soils that determines their texture

data.title: Ped
data.content: The secondary units of the primary soil particles (sand, silt, and clay)

data.title: Permeability
data.content: The ability of water to flow through a soil

data.title: pH value
data.content: Describes the number of hydrogen ions present in the soil

data.title: Porosity
data.content: The amount of void space between individual soil particles

data.title: R-layer
data.content: The deepest horizon in a soil profile; it consists of unaltered bedrock material; also called the D-horizon

data.title: Soil fertility
data.content: The ability of soil to hold sufficient nutrients for plant growth

data.title: Soil profile
data.content: The vertical section of soil from the surface layer down to where the soil meets rock

data.title: Structure
data.content: The manner in which individual soil particles aggregate

data.title: Subsoil
data.content: The horizon of a soil profile just below the topsoil (if present); it contains soil with some degree of weathering and is composed almost entirely of mineral material; also called the B-horizon

data.title: Texture
data.content: The proportion of sand, silt, and clay particles that make up the mineral fraction of the soil

data.title: Topsoil
data.content: The layer of a soil profile just below the humus layer (if present); it contains some organic matter in addition to a mixture of minerals; also called the A-horizon
